ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would not recommend this class. Despite the fascinating subject matter and the chance to go and pick a topic interesting to you to do a fairly in-depth research paper, the class was still not a particularly pleasant or enlightening experience.
Engaging, not too difficult (nor particularly rigorous), a good "rest of world" choice for history majors interested in medieval (broadly defined) European history.

You will be reading primary sources to get a picture of what it was like to live in heavily religious societies. There is a lot of reading, and not all of it is thrilling, but overall my general sense of "the big picture" with regards to the three religions improved. If you've never written a 20-page paper, this is a good class to start with because Prof. Marcus is really encouraging and will help you every step of the way. The course goes thematically, so sometimes I felt like I got lost chronologically.

I would recommend this course to someone genuinely interested in the subject material and prepared for a far larger focus on the generation of research then on stimulating class discussion. be warned that the research can be difficult simply because identifying source material for the subject can prove very time-consuming.
